... combine to make a middling, half-and-half measure experience. Bringing together the late-‘80s/early-‘90s SEGA arcade racer genre, with Asphalt’s mile-a-second arcade, super-steering, thrill ride, this game is a flat, relatively slow-paced, Sunday sight-seeing cartoon, with faux nostalgia for those who’ve never played the original, arcade, SEGA machine, bumped up, a bit, with semi-modernized gameplay that neither brings back old memories of actual ‘80s, simulated 3D camp, nor does it whiten one’s knuckles, by not slamming that genre into the trick-filled, elite-precision, supersonic, hyper-arcade experience of either of the two far better games that it struggles to jigsaw together.

Moreover, while both of the other games are free — with “A8” allowing you to watch some ads, for rewards — to go beyond the flimsy demo that this game offers *requires* payment, to fully experience its incredibly disappointing attempt to cash in on the joy of either, original game. Whereas Outrun takes you back to the whimsical glory days of late-‘80s/early-‘90s arcades — and Asphalt 8 has fine-tuning for what must be nearly 100 actual or concept, branded cars that handle and sound like their IRL counterparts — Horizon Chase has a relative handful of replicas that neither feel, nor sound like any particular car, but rather, some “hybrids” of IRL racers that, to justify the ⭐️ rating, look somewhat like super cars you’ve seen before. 

Moreover, it isn’t as exciting as either of the original games on which this game was obviously modeled, and —having gotten the PS4 version, from PS+, as a thrown-in replacement for PES Soccer, about which everyone had complained — in an unprecedented and horrible decision, by Sony — it is a one play game, which pushes against the current of sports games for which replay value is the most important aspect.

Aced the first city, not purchasing.

title.label: The soundtrack alone is worth this game

content.label: If you’ve ever wondered whether or not a 16 bit soundtrack can make you feel like you’re driving fast. The horizon chase soundtrack has an answer. Barry Leitch of Top Gear and Lotus Turbo Fame worked on this and the dynamics driving physics are unrealistic but fun. Knocking off one star because the difficulty of the Hawaii levels are too high to be enjoyable and there were much better cars you could’ve included other than a 57 Bel-Air or 3 different types of camaro.. (for example: a lotus esprit as in lotus turbo challenge not even a corvette nor a 911 replica shows up in this game.)

title.label: Needs more, but still really fun to play

content.label: Awesome, but it needs more. I love the game and how it’s developed but it lacks a lot of things that would make it REALLY good. First of all the price to buy the full version is a bit much in my opinion. Maybe $1.99 or something instead of $2.99 would work better for me. But as for the actual game, I wish there were more features other than just racing around some simplistic tracks. It would be cool to really customize your car with lots of cool options like paint, decals, body kits, wings, etc. I’d also love to see features like free roam (in  an endless city or something based on whichever region you choose), friend racing, and creating your own tracks. This would add another amazing layer to the game and would really make me want to continue playing and purchasing things in-game. It’s been 4 months as of me writing this, since the developers had their last update, so I hope they didn’t just abandon the game. I hope they listen to this and consider what I and many others are saying. Thanks :)

title.label: This is an enjoyable game, but don't expect it to give you the adrenaline rush of racing games.

content.label:
I cannot emphasize this enough: this is not a normal racing game. If you bought this game expecting to get the adrenaline rush of driving fast vehicles while balancing speed, acceleration and handling, you will be disappointed. I was. But the game is still fun for other reasons. (If you are looking for that kind of game, you should go with GRID, Asphalt, Real Racing. Or maybe Forza, Project CARS.)

This game is about dodging other cars. There is no worry of losing traction around a tight corner. There is no worry of being on the outside of the track before the tight corner or controlling your speed so it is just low enough to make that corner. Sometimes, if you pick a car with low handling in this game, yes you need to decelerate before a corner in order to avoid hitting the signposts on the outside, but most of the time, you lose speed because you rear-end other cars or because the car next to you pushes you onto the trees (causing your car to spin cartoonishly).

Your car is always faster than other cars. The cars you unlock in this game do not get significantly faster or better in handling over the course of the game. They do get better, but not as drastically as in other games, where you can go from driving a Ford Focus to a McLaren F1. In general, most cars feel kind of the same, and even when they feel different, such as going from a car with low handling but high speed to a car with high handling but low speed, these traits do not impact your gameplay in the same way as in other games.

This game is very easy, and that can be boring. Most of the time, I can beat a level with nearly 130 points out of 120 (there are bonus points) on the first go, without ever having seen the level before. And that's because you don't really need to get used to the level. You just need to be proficient at dodging other cars and being mindful of where the coins are. If I do replay a level, it is usually because the coins are in parallel on three different lanes, so I need to be on a different lane on each of the three laps, and I forgot to do that on the first go.

It is definitely very frustrating when this happens: that you need to replay a level because you didn't manage to collect all of the coins, rather than because you didn't handle your car optimally. It is frustrating when the reason you miss out either on first place or on collecting all coins is because other cars starting bumping you like mad. These things don't happen in normal racing games, which are usually all about the polish of handling all of the corners of the track and knowing the handling of your car well.

It is still fun because you always get to go very fast, and managing to dodge other cars is rewarding (though this does very often come down to luck, sigh). This game is also beautiful. It is blocky and abstract, but the scenes are colorful and you can even tell that they applied shadow on the falling snow in the twilight.

Lastly, I just wanted to mention that I enjoy this a lot more on iPad, but the resolution is not optimized for 12.9-inch iPad Pro. There are extra black bezels.
